content: I just updated my code to Lean 4.9.0 and am adapting it to use the new Lean.AssocList instead of the old Std.AssocList (now batteries). The conversion of List of pairs to AssocList was usually done by toAssocList, But the Lean standard library calls it toAssocList'. Any special reason for ending it with '?

What gave you the idea that there is a new Lean.AssocList? Nothing has fundamentally changed about the two types called AssocList in a long time, except that what used to be called Std.AssocList is now called Batteries.AssocList. The name List.toAssocList can only be used by one function, and it seems that batteries uses it for the function that returns a Batteries.AssocList, so the function that returns a Lean.AssocList must use a different name, and that different name is List.toAssocList'.

I see, so the answer to my question is that the ' in the name does not have any special meaning that could suggest any tendency to a deprecated status. I got that toAssocList needs to be in the List namespace to be used in the dot notation, so this forces the existence of the two names.
Alexandre Rademaker has marked this topic as resolved.
